Slave ‚Äì Something that is being controlled by some other MIDI clock source. A MIDI clip‚Äôs timing may be controlled by the master tempo of the DAW, for example.

Snare ‚Äì A common type of drum, characterised by a peak around ~150Hz-200Hz and some high-end noise.

Soft Clipping ‚Äì A type of distortion created by driving a signal beyond 0dB. Soft clipping differs from hard clipping, as it ‚Äòrounds‚Äô the waveform off as opposed to slicing it off, allowing it to sound more subtle.

Soft Synth ‚Äì A synthesiser that exists inside a computer, like Serum or Massive.

Solo ‚Äì A control that temporarily silences all channels besides the selected one.

Song ‚Äì Traditionally, a song is a track that features vocals.

Sound ‚Äì See ‚ÄòAudio‚Äô.

SoundCloud ‚Äì Where rappers live. Just kidding, it‚Äôs a major streaming platform that allows artists to upload their works directly to the platform, unlike Spotify etc.

Sound Pressure Level (SPL) ‚Äì A measurement of decibels in the physical world. It‚Äôs what normies mean when they say, ‚Äòthat‚Äôs like 100 decibels!!!‚Äô

Soundproofing ‚Äì The act of using damping materials in a room to reduce reflections, and to stop sound from escaping and coming into the area.

Sound System ‚Äì A collection of loudspeakers, subwoofers and amplifiers that work together to produce sound, usually in a live venue.

Soundtoys ‚Äì A plugin company that creates FX plugins inspired by older hardware units, with new creative features. Check out Crrystaliser for sure.

Sound Waves ‚Äì See ‚ÄòWaveform‚Äô.

Source ‚Äì Any place where audio or data originates from.

Speaker ‚Äì Short for ‚ÄòLoudspeaker‚Äô.

Spectrum ‚Äì Refers to the range of frequencies in the audible realm.

Spectrum Analyzer ‚Äì Graphically represents the amplitude of all frequencies in the audible spectrum.

Splice ‚Äì A company that has a sample subscription service, a project file sharing service, and many other useful tools for producers.

Spotify ‚Äì A popular streaming service that artists can distribute their music to.

Spring Reverb ‚Äì A type of reverb that is created by sending an electrical signal through a spring.

Square ‚Äì A wave found in most subtractive synthesisers. Sounds bright and hollow. Can be created from any sound if you distort it enough.

Stems ‚Äì The individual audio tracks rendered from a finished track, usually used for remix purposes.

Stereo ‚Äì Any sound that contains both left and right channel information.

Stereo Image ‚Äì Refers to the level of difference between the content in the left channel and the right channel. The more difference in content, the wider the mix will sound.

Stock ‚Äì Any sound, device or preset that comes with the software it was designed to be used with. Ableton‚Äôs audio effects are called ‚Äòstock‚Äô for this reason.

Stop ‚Äì A control that stops playback.

Strings ‚Äì An instrument that features a string played by a bow. Many synths have also recreated this sound.

Sub Bass ‚Äì Bass in the range of under around 70Hz.

Subgroup ‚Äì A group of audio tracks, usually that itself belongs to another group.

Subtractive Synthesis ‚Äì A form of synthesis that works by starting with basic waves (sine, saw, square, triangle) and ‚Äòsubtracts‚Äô through the use of envelopes, filters, and LFO‚Äôs.

Subwoofer ‚Äì A loudspeaker designed to reproduce frequencies under ~200Hz only.

Summing ‚Äì The process of adding waveforms from different sources together.

Supersaw ‚Äì A saw wave with unison and detune, usually with around 8 voices. Sounds very wide and big.

Surround Sound ‚Äì A sound system featuring a ratio of 5 speakers arranged in a space at different angles, and 1 subwoofer for bass. The angles of the speakers give an illusion of 360-degree sound.

Sustain ‚Äì An ADSR control on a synth that determines the level that the synth will decay to (in decibels).

Sync ‚Äì A type of oscillator modulator that duplicates the wave in the same cycle space, creating a sort of pitching effect that still keeps the same fundamental pitch.

Sylenth1 ‚Äì A subtractive soft synth created by LennarDigital that is ideal for creating analogue-type sounds.

Synthesizer (Synth) ‚Äì An electronic instrument that creates sound by using oscillators and a series of processing.

T

Take ‚Äì A singular recording of audio. Usually, multiple takes will be done to achieve a good recording.

Talkbox ‚Äì A vocoder-like effect that uses the voice to modulate an instrument, like a guitar. Unlike a vocoder, speech is not usually as intelligible and only vowel sounds are heard.

Tap Tempo ‚Äì A control on a delay where tapping determines the bpm for the delay time.

Tape Delay ‚Äì Delay that occurs by writing the audio file onto tape and playing it back at a determined interval. Usually has a pitch warble due to the imperfections.

Tape Hiss ‚Äì A byproduct when recording something to a tape or cassette tape due to a low noise floor.

TDM (Time-Division Multiplexing) ‚Äì Okay, so apparently this is a thing. Apart from it sounding like something straight out of Doctor Who, TDM refers to Pro Tools plugins specifically used on systems with dedicated DSP processors for high-quality processing without straining your computer ‚Äì found in very high-end studios only. Frees up the CPU for more Serum, I guess.

Tempo ‚Äì Measured in Beats per Minute, the tempo determines the speed of the track.

Test ‚Äì A render of an incomplete track that is used to be tested on multiple systems.

Thin ‚Äì Used to describe when a sound doesn‚Äôt have much of a body, usually containing only mids and highs.

Threshold ‚Äì A control on a compressor (or other devices) that determines when the compressor will start compressing (a specific dB level).

Timbre ‚Äì The quality of a sound that distinguishes it from other sounds, based on factors like frequency content, amplitude, modulation and other factors.

Top-line ‚Äì A vocal or lead line that acts as the hook point of a track, usually with a strong melody or with memorable lyrics.

Toms ‚Äì A type of drum in the low-mid rs he that keeps rhythm. Usually comes in sets of 3-4, set at different pitches.

Tone ‚Äì A single frequency.

Tone Generator ‚Äì A device that generates a tone, usually for pitch correction purposes.

Track ‚Äì Either means a full piece of digital music, or an individual audio channel in the production process.

Traktor ‚Äì A DJing system created by Native Instruments that includes a range of controllers, and the Traktor Pro software.

Transient ‚Äì The initial start point of a drum sound, where the audio goes from near silence to sudden loudness. Sounds clicky.

Transient Shaper ‚Äì An effect designed to analyse where transients are in a sound and make them louder or softer.

Transpose ‚Äì The process of moving notes or audio up or down in semitones.

Transport ‚Äì A section of a DAW that houses the play, stop, record and other buttons.

Trap (Genre) ‚Äì A genre of music that combines hip-hop and rap elements with bass music (a la dubstep) elements.

Tremolo ‚Äì Subtle volume modulation with an LFO to achieve a movement in a sound.

Triangle ‚Äì A wave in most subtractive synths that sounds like a sine wave with a few more harmonics.

Trigger ‚Äì When pressing a button on a MIDI controller activated something on a piece of software, usually a sound.

Trim ‚Äì A gain control on some audio effects to counteract an increase in volume introduced by some effects.

Truncate ‚Äì What happens to a wave when it has been hard clipped ‚Äì it chops the top of the wave off at 0db with sharp edges.

Tube ‚Äì A distortion type that sounds (and emulates) like it is being driven through an analog vacuum tube.

Tune ‚ÄìA control on an electronic instrument that determines the pitch of an oscillator (in cents).

Tuner ‚Äì A device that listens to audio to measure if it is in tune.

Turntable ‚Äì A player that plays vinyl records. Can be used for playback and/or DJing.

Tweak ‚Äì Adjusting a control on a device. DJs pretend to do this to look cool.

Tweeter ‚Äì A speaker come designed to reproduce high frequencies around 10-20kHz. Usually featured above the main cone on a pair of studio monitors.

U

Underground ‚Äì Describes any music or related culture that is the opposite of mainstream.

Unison ‚Äì A control on many synthesisers that layer the same oscillator voice over each other with slight detuning, to create a thick sound. Very popular in trance and future bass.

Unity Gain ‚Äì When the audio level of audio is preserved after processing. For example, distortion may be applied to a sound, adding loudness as well as extra harmonics, but the output gain it turned down so the level is the same after the processing.

USB ‚Äì Stands for Universal Serial Bus. A standard socket on many computers and devices that allow things to be connected to a computer and transfer MIDI information. If you‚Äôve got a computer, you‚Äôve got a USB port.

Utility ‚Äì A device in Ableton that allows the adjustment of technical parts of the sound, like gain, phase, panning, DC offset and more.

V

VBR ‚Äì Variable Bit Rate. When an MP3 or lossy audio file has a bit rate that changes with the type of content in the file. Good for maximising audio quality while still saving space.

VCA ‚Äì Voltage Controlled Amplifier. The section on an analogue synth that controls the ADSR envelope and the volume.

VCF ‚Äì Voltage Controller Filter. The section on an analogue synth that controls the filter and the filter ADSR.

VCO ‚Äì Voltage Controlled Oscillator. An oscillator on an analogue synth.

Velocity ‚Äì A MIDI parameter for each note that is played, usually determining the loudness of that notes. Emulates the effect of playing a piano or physical instrument at different levels of loudness.

Verse ‚Äì A section of a vocal track that normally comes after the intro. Individual verses usually only feature once per track, with future verses sounding similar but containing different lyrics.

Vibrato ‚Äì An audio effect achieved by modulating the pitch of a sound with an LFO at a small amplitude. Sounds wavy.

Vinyl ‚Äì A physical format of music created by inscribing the waveform onto a wax disc, reproduced by playing it with a needle on a turntable, so that the needle vibrates in real time, reproducing the audio.

Vinyl Distortion ‚Äì A type of distortion represented by poor dynamics on an old/broken vinyl record.

Virtual Instrument ‚Äì An instrument in the digital domain, usually in plugin form, that is used to create sound much like a traditional instrument would.

Vocal ‚Äì A recorded piece of audio of somebody singing.

Vocal Booth ‚Äì A small space with soundproofing and isolation designed to record vocals in.

Vocoder ‚Äì An audio effect that uses a carrier (the effected sound) and a modulator (the effecting sound) to create a superimposition of sound. Usually, the voice acts as a modulator and a synth acts as the carrier, and this creates a robotic sort of voice sound. Still unsure? Go listen to Daft Punk.

Voice ‚Äì Something generated by a synthesiser. Adding unison to an oscillator, or using multiple oscillators, will increase the amount of voices created by a synth.

Volume ‚Äì The amplitude of a sound. Usually, a parameter that can be adjusted on a device.

Vox ‚Äì Short for vocals.

VST (Virtual Studio Technology) ‚Äì A plugin format developed by Steinberg (for Cubase) that has been adopted as one of the industry standards. Probably the most popular plugin format.

VU Meter ‚Äì Stands for ‚ÄòVolume Unit Meter‚Äô, and is a way of measuring audio in the analog domain. All VU meters, where digital or analog, feature a needle that moves with the audio, and has a slower response to represent average loudness as opposed to peak volume.

W

Warm ‚Äì A vague term that describes anything with an analog feel. This can mean anything with noticeable low-mid information, subtle noise in the signal, reduced high-end frequencies and many more audible effects.

Warp ‚Äì Has many meanings, but usually refers to the warp algorithms in Ableton or other DAWs that change the timing and pitch of audio, mostly to keep it in time with the DAW‚Äôs clock tempo. DAWs have different warping algorithms that are suited to different types of audio, like drums, synths or vocals.

Wavefolding ‚Äì A audio effect that processes audio when it reaches a threshold in a variety of ways, usually by folding the waveform back in on itself instead of clipping or compressing. Creates an interesting type of distortion.

Waveform ‚Äì An audio signal represented visually as a wave.

Wavelength ‚Äì Refers to the length of one cycle of a sine wave. As frequency increases, wavelength decreases.

Waves ‚Äì A brand of audio plugins for music production. Check out our plugin roundup here.

Waveshaper ‚Äì An audio effect that recreates a variety of distortion algorithms through an input/output envelope. All types of digital distortion are essentially ‚Äòpossible‚Äô with a wave shaper, but it is not ideal for recreating analog distortion.

Wavetable ‚Äì A series of waveform cycles that can be scanned through in a wavetable synthesiser.

Wavetable Synthesis ‚Äì A form of synthesis similar to subtractive synthesis, but instead oscillators can feature a wider variety of waveforms, sometimes with the ability to customise them. Xfer Serum, NI Massive and Ableton Wavetable are three very popular Wavetable Synthesisers.

WAV (Waveform Audio File Format) ‚Äì A standard lossless audio file format used for its high quality. Most samples, stems and other production-related audio files typically come in WAV format. WAV cannot have the same ID3 tags that an MP3 or AIFF does.

Wet ‚Äì A processed version of a signal, as opposed to the dry, which is the unprocessed signal. A wet signal can be blended in with a Dry/Wet knob.

White Noise ‚Äì A noise produced by many synthesisers that is the result of playing the entire frequency spectrum at once.

Whole Step ‚Äì A movement of two notes in a given direction.

Woodwind ‚Äì A group of traditional instruments that generate sound by wind passing through. Includes flutes, saxophones, clarinets, oboes and more.

Woofer ‚Äì A loudspeaker driver that reproduces the low-mid frequencies, usually from ~40Hz up to ~500Hz. Similar to a subwoofer but with a higher range.

WOW ‚Äì A type of filter that creates formants. Usually refers to the plugin created by Sugar Bytes which is a filter that does exactly that. Sometimes people make this noise when trying to recreate dubstep with their mouths.

X

XLR ‚Äì A standard electrical cable/connector in audio that features three pins and is round. Found on many mixers and audio interfaces.

Y

YouTube Music ‚Äì A streaming service by YouTube that artists can distribute their music to.

Z

Zero-crossing ‚Äì A point on a waveform that passes through the central zero line (silence).
